Another interesting thing about having a CPPN with two outputs (one
for eac=
h layer) is that theoretically you can get two weights out for
each single =
complete activation of the CPPN.  We probably did not
leverage this capabil=
ity in this paper because we only have one
output, but if there were many o=
utputs (as there are many inputs and
hidden nodes) then it might save some =
computation time.

Anyway, like Jason said, this setup is based on an intui=
tion about
separability, so I am suspecting that there are pros and cons to=
 both
alternatives (i.e. using z vs. having 2 outputs) that are
domain-spec=
ific.  This paper does not constitute an exhaustive study
of the issue.  Ho=
wever, it does show that the multi-output approach,
which is perhaps not th=
e one that first comes to mind, can work.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com=
, "Jason Gauci" <jgmath2000@...> wrote:
>
> Hey Stephen,
> 
> Great questio=
ns!  We'll have to think about some of them for awhile
> but here's a few a=
nswers:
> 
> The reason why I chose to use a separate output for each conne=
ction
> layer instead of using a 3-dimensional CPPN is because I wanted to
=
> separate the network for each layer.  If you use the 3-D CPPN method,
> t=
hen the two layers are only distinguished by the values of 'z'. 
> Because =
I'm only using two layers, I wanted to make sure that each
> layer did some=
 unique processing.  If there was only one output, it
> would be harder for=
 the connection layers to distinguish themselves as
> they would be too dep=
endent.  In the worst case, z1 and z2 inputs are
> not used and the two lay=
ers are exactly the same. I haven't done any
> empirical tests on which met=
hod is better so I do not have any
> evidence to back my claim, but it's my=
 intuition.
> 
> I haven't tried any computer opponents other than Xchecker=
s.  I have
> had my friends and people in the lab play against the HyperNEA=
T
> opponent and it is definitely better than all of us :-).  I would like
=
> to release a binary version so people can play the opponents at
> differe=
nt generations and see the change in performance.
> 
> One active area of i=
nterest is to figure out how good a HyperNEAT
> player is in a global sense=
.  In Chellapilla & Fogel's paper, they
> played human opponents in checker=
s on MSN Gaming Zone online and got
> an expert rating on that game server.=
  The problem with this is that
> it is very time consuming to play games b=
y hand. It would not be
> feasible for me to test several individuals in th=
is way.
> 
> I have experimented with coevolution, but I need to solve the
=
> aforementioned problem before I can say anything about the performance
> =
of the evolved individuals.
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Stephen Waits=
 <steve@> wrote:
> >
> > 
> > On Apr 11, 2008, at 9:38 PM, Kenneth Stanley =
wrote:
> > > Jason Gauci and I are pleased to share with you new results wi=
th
> > > HyperNEAT  in our new paper to appear in the Twenty-Third AAAI
> >=
 > Conference on Artificial Intelligence (2008), "A Case Study on the
> > >=
 Critical Role of Geometric Regularity in Machine Learning."
> > 
> > 
> > =
Cool, I enjoyed the paper, thanks Jason and Ken.
> > 
> > I have a few ques=
tions:
> > 
> > * Was the 4in/2out CPPN arbitrarily chosen?
> > * Why not a=
 6in/1out (xyz, xyz, out) - which seems more natural to me?
> > * Was more =
than one CPPN configuration tried?  What was the process?
> > * Was more th=
an one substrate configuration tried?  ...
> > * What was the full connecti=
on pattern through the substrate?  You  
> > mention the 129 nodes (which m=
akes sense), but what are the 3979  
> > connections?
> > * Did you try aga=
inst any opponents other than Xcheckers?
> > * Have you experimented with c=
oevolution?
> > 
> > Thanks again for the great work.

its
